<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 170, 290]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 291]]<|/det|> **0625/53** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 905, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test **October/November 2018** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 322, 905, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour 15 minutes** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 353]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 580, 372]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 393, 388, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 781, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 330, 446]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 501, 461]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 504, 475]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 904, 543]]<|/det|> You are advised to spend about 20 minutes on each of questions 1 to 3, and about 15 minutes on question 4. Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 767, 557]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 571, 605, 583]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 757, 597]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 655, 905, 848]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 415, 729, 434]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 445, 695, 464]]<|/det|>

Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 453, 737, 470]]<|/det|>
• Connect the crocodile clip \(\mathbf{C}\) to the free end of the resistance wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 917, 516]]<|/det|>
• Switch on. Adjust the position of the crocodile clip \(\mathbf{C}\) until the current shown on the ammeter is as near to 0.40A as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 917, 562]]<|/det|>
• Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across wire \(\mathbf{X}\). Switch off.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 702, 593]]<|/det|>
• Repeat the procedure for \(I = 0.50\mathsf{A}\) , 0.60A, 0.70A and 0.80A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 750, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by a plane mirror.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 905, 588]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 605, 532, 622]]<|/det|>
<pre><center>Fig. 3.1 </center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 636, 146, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 814, 669]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. Refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 682, 880, 699]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line about 10cm from the bottom of your ray-trace sheet. Label this line \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 713, 510, 730]]<|/det|>
• Mark a point \(\mathbf{N}\), near the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 744, 917, 777]]<|/det|>
• Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{AB}\) at point \(\mathbf{N}\), towards the top of the page. Label the other end of this normal line \(\mathbf{L}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 790, 146, 808]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 790, 768, 808]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{CD}\) passing through \(\mathbf{N}\) and at an angle \(\alpha\) to \(\mathbf{AB}\) where \(\alpha = 20^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 790, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 144, 93]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 75, 918, 110]]<|/det|> • Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{LN}\) , a suitable distance apart for ray tracing. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 121, 918, 155]]<|/det|> • Place the reflecting surface of the mirror on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and view the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 168, 918, 202]]<|/det|> • Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) some distance apart so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , and the pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) , all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 462, 231]]<|/det|> • Remove the mirror and the pins. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 245, 769, 263]]<|/det|> • Draw a line passing through the \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) positions and reaching \(\mathbf{LN}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 276, 870, 293]]<|/det|> • Measure and record in Table 3.1, the angle \(\theta\) between this line and the normal \(\mathbf{LN}\). <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 335, 652, 411]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha /\text {'}\)\(\theta /\text {'}\)

35

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 690, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the conduction of thermal energy by metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 863, 120]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to compare the rates at which different metals conduct thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 522, 151]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 398, 181]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 595, 212]]<|/det|>
strips of different metals, shaped as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 214, 388, 228]]<|/det|>
a test-tube in a clamp stand

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 230, 235, 243]]<|/det|>
a beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 246, 339, 259]]<|/det|>
a supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 261, 333, 275]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 288, 528, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 446, 531, 462]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 477, 662, 493]]<|/det|>
<pre>The shorter section of each strip of metal can fit inside a test-tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 508, 380, 523]]<|/det|>
<pre>Write a plan for the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 539, 218, 554]]<|/det|>
<pre>You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 570, 456, 585]]<|/det|>
<pre>• list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 601, 670, 616]]<|/det|>
<pre>• draw a labelled diagram of how the apparatus will be arranged

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 632, 583, 647]]<|/det|>
<pre>• explain briefly how you will carry out the experiment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 663, 494, 678]]<|/det|>
<pre>• explain how the metals will be compared

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 694, 724, 709]]<|/det|>
<pre>• state the precautions which should be taken to obtain reliable results.
